headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Microsoft Corporation Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.I would now like to turn the conference over to Chris Suh, General Manager of Investo
componenttext:
Welcome to the Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Microsoft Corporation Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Chris Suh, General Manager of Investor Relations. Chris, please proceed.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. On the call with me today are Satya Nadella, Chief Executive Officer; Amy Hood, Chief Financial Officer; Frank Brod, Chief Accounting Officer; and John Seethoff, Deputy General Counsel.On ou
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. On the call with me today are Satya Nadella, Chief Executive Officer; Amy Hood, Chief Financial Officer; Frank Brod, Chief Accounting Officer; and John Seethoff, Deputy General Counsel.
On our website, microsoft.com/investor, we have posted our financial summary slide deck, which is intended to follow our prepared remarks and provide the reconciliation of differences between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures. The non-GAAP measures exclude the impact of the impairment, integration and restructuring charges and are included as additional clarifying item to aid investors in further understanding the company's fourth quarter and fiscal year performance and the impact of these items and events has on the financial results. The non-GAAP financial measures provided above should not be considered as substitute for or superior to the measures of financial performance prepared in accordance with GAAP.
Unless otherwise specified, we will refer to non-GAAP metrics on the call. All growth comparisons we make on the call relate to the corresponding period of last year, unless otherwise noted. For selected metrics on the call and in other earnings materials, we have provided growth rates in constant currency. We present constant currency information to provide a framework for assessing how our underlying business is performed, excluding the effect of foreign currency rate fluctuation.
Additionally, any mention of operating expense refers to segment operating expenses as defined in the footnotes of our 10-K and includes research and development, sales and marketing and general and administrative, but excludes the impact of impairment, integration and restructuring charges.
We will post the prepared remarks to our website immediately following the call until the complete transcript is available. Today's call is being webcast live and recorded. If you ask a question, it will be included in our live transmission, in the transcript and in any future use of the recording. You can replay the call and view the transcript at the Microsoft Investor Relations website until July 21, 2016.
During this call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are predictions, projections or other statements about future events. These statements are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Actual results could materially differ because of factors discussed in today's earnings press release, in the comments made during this conference call and in the Risk Factors section of our Form 10-K, Form 10-Q and other reports and filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. We do not undertake any duty to update any forward-looking statement.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Satya.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, we will share the results of the final quarter of the year and our optimism for the year ahead. We delivered $22.2 billion in revenue this quarter and $93.6 billion in total revenue for the fiscal year '1
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, we will share the results of the final quarter of the year and our optimism for the year ahead. We delivered $22.2 billion in revenue this quarter and $93.6 billion in total revenue for the fiscal year '15, an increase in 8% year-over-year. We push forward in our transformation by focusing our investment in areas where we have differentiation and significant opportunity for future growth in large, addressable markets. We galvanized around our mission and ambitions. We aligned our structure to deliver better product at a more rapid pace, we focused our advertising business on search, we focused on mapping efforts on higher level experiences and developer services. We restructured our phone portfolio so that we can operate more efficiently near term while driving reinvention long term. We invested more in the new mobile applications like Wanderlust, Sunrise. We also strengthened our enterprise cloud platform by acquiring Revolution Analytics, DataZen and Blue Stripe in this quarter alone, and we are at the threshold of the Windows 10 launch.
I'm proud of these steps and I'm proud of the results we delivered in tandem. In cloud alone, our annualized Commercial cloud run rate surpassed $8 billion this quarter and the revenue grew 88% year-over-year. We're on a strong trajectory towards our goal of $20 billion in fiscal year '18.
With that as the backdrop, I want to walk you through the progress we are making in each one of our 3 ambitions.
Let me start with reinventing productivity and business processes, including our efforts across Office 365 and Dynamics. We continue to see strong demand for Office 365 and Dynamics products. We now have more than 15 million Office 365 customers -- consumer subscribers and customers are signing up at a pace of nearly 1 million per month. In addition, we surpassed 150 million downloads of Office Mobile on iOS and Android and have introduced a new version of Office for the Mac. 
In the Commercial space, the number of Office 365 users continues to climb with seats growing 74% year-over-year. Office 365 now is in 4 out of 5 Fortune 500 enterprises and more than 55% of the installed base is on premium workload. It is clear that we success moving customers to the cloud, even half of all the Enterprise Agreement renewals were for Office 365 this quarter. 
Small and medium businesses offer one of our best opportunities for new growth in the cloud. In fact for more than one year now, we have seen 50,000 new SMB customers adopt Office 365 every month. Last week at our Worldwide Partner Conference, we announced our new Office 365 premium SKU for business, E5. Now our customers will get rich, new voice functionality in Skype for Business with cloud PBX and DST and conferencing, deep analytics with DALBAR analytics and Power BI Pro and advanced security features such as Lockbox and advanced threat protection. With E5, we've expanded our market opportunity for Office 365 by more than $50 billion. This new E5 SKU and the launch of Office 2016 will drive one of the biggest new businesses for us.
Let's now turn to CRM. This market alone is $20 billion plus and has massive opportunity for reinvention. Mainstreaming Dynamics into our engineering, sales and marketing efforts gives us the ability to participate in this large and growing market in a more meaningful way. Last week, we announced the acquisition of Field One, which helps strengthen our Dynamics CRM customer service offering. This quarter, total paid seats for Dynamics CRM Online increased 140% year-over-year, and we have more than 8 million paid dynamic seats across CRM and ERP in total, up 25% year-over-year. This creates a great foundation for future growth in our Dynamics business.
Next, I want to share our progress in building the intelligent cloud platform with Azure. Again, this quarter, we have seen proved preference for our cloud SaaS services creates a flywheel the growth for our cloud platform services. In Azure, both revenue and compete usage increased by triple digit year-over-year. We tripled our revenue from Azure premium services this quarter and the Enterprise Mobility services we now have 17,000 customers. Appeal for Visual Studio tools has grown to include developers beyond our traditional base, with some of the decisions we make to embrace Open Source, .NET and support cross-platform development. Since November, we have seen more than 5 million downloads of Visual Studio community, the fastest-ever adoption of a Visual Studio product. Visual Studio Online continues to gain momentum with over 3.1 million registered users.
Business intelligence and analytics is another large rapidly growing market for us with an opportunity of more than $50 billion. We are focused on strengthening our offers in this space. Just last week, we announced the availability of Cortana analytics suite, a fully managed big data and advanced analytics solutions. We are not only building the tools but they're also delivering the insights customers need to transform their businesses.
Security is a key priority for our enterprise customers and another $30 billion market opportunity for us, and we are building capably to meet customers' needs. For example, we have made significant investments in security with Azure Tybalt enabling our customers to protect data in the cloud security management and encryption capable customers in control. We have 4 new certifications for Azure, bringing our certification at a station total to 22 globally, more than any other cloud platform today.
Our third bold ambition is to create more personal computing experiences with Windows and our devices. I'm thrilled we are just days away from the start of Windows 10. It's the first step towards our goal of 1 billion Windows 10 active devices in the fiscal year '18. Our aspiration with Windows 10 is to move people from needing to choosing to lovingly Windows. Based on feedback for more than 5 million people who have been using Windows 10, we believe people the love the familiarity of Windows 10 and the innovation. It's safe, secure and always up-to-date. 
Windows 10 is more personal and more productive with Cortana, Office, Universal apps and Continue. And Windows 10 will deliver innovative new experiences, like inking on Microsoft Edge and gaming across Xbox and PCs and also opens up entirely new device categories such as HoloLens. 
Windows 10 will deliver significant value to enterprise customers as well. Windows 10 provides advanced security capabilities with additional features for hardware-based security, more work and data protection. It also provides the single device management platform across all devices from phones to laptops to Internet of Things devices. And Windows 10 helps enterprises stay up-to-date with Windows Update for business and Windows Store for business.
While the PC ecosystem has been under pressure recently, I do believe that Windows 10 will broaden our economic opportunity and return Windows to growth.
First, we have an OEM ecosystem that is creating exciting new hardware designs for Windows 10. In fact, our OEM partners have over 2,000 distinct devices or configurations already in testing for Windows 10 upgrades, as well as hundreds of new hardware designs. We are delighted that the first of these exciting new devices will start to be available on Windows 10 launch day. And by this holiday, we will be selling the widest range of Windows hardware ever available.
Second, we will generate new growth through gross margin on our own differentiated first-party, premium-device portfolio. We will also significantly reduce our losses on the phone by operating more effectively and efficiently with a more focused portfolio. 
Third, we will grow monetization opportunities across the commercial and consumer space. In the enterprise, customers will continue to value our unparalleled management, security, and servicing capability. And for consumers, Windows 10 creates monetization opportunities with store, search and gaming. We are confident that these are the right levers to revitalize Windows and restore growth. The progress we make this quarter and the forward-looking guidance that Amy will share shows the opportunity for renewed growth is real.
In hardware, both Surface and Xbox, had an incredible Q4. We more than doubled Surface revenue to nearly $900 million this quarter, capping off a year in which it delivered more than $3.6 billion in revenue. Both consumers and enterprise customers love this device. Surface is clearly a product where we've gotten the formula right, earned fans and can apply this formula to other parts of the hardware portfolio. 
Gaming is an important scenario for Windows 10 and our success with Xbox this quarter gives us a strong starting position heading into launch. Xbox Live users grew 22% this quarter and logged nearly 3.5 billion hours of game play. Our growing fan base is excited for the best games line up in our history. All of this comes together with Windows 10 when fans can connect with each other, stream all of their Xbox One games to Windows 10 and experience the best virtual reality platform given our partnership with Oculus Rift and valve.
In search, Bing will now power both differentiated experience on Windows 10 such as Cortana, as well as search and advertising across the AOL portfolio sites in the partnership we already have with Yahoo!, Amazon and Apple. With advertising revenue growth of 21% year-over-year, Bing will transition to profitability in the coming fiscal year.
It's been a strong year of progress. Above all else, I'm optimistic about our future. Our cloud services are accelerating fast and Windows is positioned for renewed growth. 
With that, I'll hand it over to Amy to talk about this quarter's results in more detail. I look forward to rejoining you after that for questions. Thank you.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good afternoon, everyone. Our fourth quarter results demonstrates the strong progress that we've made as a company over the past year. Key strategic initiatives such as cloud, first-party hardware and consumer services delivers significant gro
componenttext:
Thanks, and good afternoon, everyone. Our fourth quarter results demonstrates the strong progress that we've made as a company over the past year. Key strategic initiatives such as cloud, first-party hardware and consumer services delivers significant growth as well as improved profitability.
Commercial customer renewals remained healthy, with strong adoption of cloud services and a higher mix of annuity than we expected. And our disciplined approach to resource allocation has allowed us to increase investment in the growth initiatives Satya mentioned while reducing the company's operating expenses. This allows us to better compete in markets with structural growth, where we feel we have unique competitive advantages.
With that said, I will start with an overview of our financial performance before moving into a more detailed discussion of the results.
This quarter, we recorded an impairment charge related to our foreign hardware business and incurred integration and restructuring expenses. Additionally, like most multinational companies compassed of the U.S. dollar continues to have a significant impact on our reported results. Accordingly, when applicable, I'll give results and growth rates adjusting for the impairment, integration and restructuring expenses but also in constant currency to help you better understand the underlying business fundamentals.
Revenue was $22.2 billion, down 5% and down 2% in constant currency. As a reminder, last year included $382 million of revenue that we recognized at the conclusion of our commercial agreement with Nokia. Significant gross margin improvement across commercial cloud, Surface and our consumer services helped to mitigate the impact on gross margin from the decline in the D&C Licensing. Total gross margin declined 7% and 3% in constant currency.
Operating income declined 3% and 1% in constant currency. Earnings per share was $0.62, growth of 11% and growth of 8% in constant currency. Unearned revenue grew 1% to $25.3 billion and 7% in constant currency. Commercial unearned was better than expected as we saw a higher mix of annuity in the quarter.
From a geographic perspective, the majority of markets performed in line with our expectation. The notable exception was Brazil, where inflation and macroeconomic volatility weighed on our performance. Overall, macro conditions remain a challenge in some large opportunity markets like China, Russia, Japan and Brazil. There is slightly less impact from currency than our expectation. With that backdrop, I'll move to a detailed discussion of our results.
Q4 last year effectively marked the end of the XP refresh cycle. If impacted our Windows OEM and non-annuity volume licensing as well as our Office non-annuity volume licensing results. During that time, OEM revenue exceeded that of the underlying PC market driven by a higher attach to Pro, particularly within the developed markets. This quarter Pro declined by roughly 21% and similar to last quarter, we saw Pro-attach remain at pre-XP level, even with the underlying softness in the business piece of the market. The annuity portion of Windows volume licensing grew again on a constant currency basis with non-annuity revenue declining due to XP.
Windows non-Pro revenue declined 27% as OEMs tightly managed PC inventory ahead of the Windows 10 launch, particularly in developed markets. In our view, this is a healthy state for the channel and we hit into a transformational launch that starts next week.
Consumer Office 365 had another strong quarter of net subscriber growth. Overall, Consumer Office revenue results net reflected the decline in the underlying driver of that business, developed market consumer PC sales. Within D&C Licensing, the transition to Office 365 accounted for 13 points and the impact of Japan's PC market accounted for another 19 points.
We had another impressive quarter in search, with revenue growth of 21% and 25% in constant currency, driven by increases in both volume and revenue per search. As Satya said, revenue from service more than doubled this quarter, with continued strength of Surface Pro 3 and the launch of Surface 3. 
Enterprise sales accelerated this quarter and sales of Surface 3 were particularly strong to educational customers. Our differentiated products, as well as improved discipline and execution, helped to improve gross margin by over $450 million this quarter and $1.3 billion in fiscal '15.
Within Xbox, strong growth at consoles, online transactions and first party games helped to drive revenue growth to 27%. This progress, as well as the excitement that we generated at E3 with Xbox, exclusive gaming content and backwards compatibility, demonstrates the building momentum that exists within the Xbox ecosystem.
In phones, we sold 8.4 million Lumias, which is an increase over last year's full quarter sales. ASPs, however, have continued to decline. Gross margin declined this quarter driven by lower per unit volumes on Lumia devices as well as reduced volumes in non-Lumia phones. As announced on July 8, we are changing that approach in this business and are focused on delivering differentiated experiences for our target customer segment while improving our operating results.
Moving to our commercial results. Total revenue across our 2 segments grew slightly in USCs and grew 4% at constant currency. Our contracted not billed balance, which is a key indicator of customer commitment, reached an all-time high of over $24.5 billion and it reached this level even with the significant appreciation in the U.S. dollar. Constant currency bookings were flat to the prior year, though as a reminder, last year commercial bookings were 23% on the strength of a large renewal base as well as the end of XP discussed earlier.
Our Office Commercial business continues to transition to Office 365. We again grew the installed seat base of Office, Exchange, SharePoint and Skype for Business. Office 365 allows us to have a deeper ongoing relationship with all of our customers, which in turn provide us with the opportunity to expand and grow our business over time.
Because of this transition, as well as weakness in Japan and the impact of XP, Office Commercial products and services grew 1% in constant currency, quite similar to Q3. Dynamics revenue grew 15% on a constant currency basis, driven by the strong CRM results that we talked about and our ERP business, which saw 35% growth in customers this quarter. Server products and services grew 4% and 9% in constant currency, continuing to outperform our peers in the enterprise software sector. People server share growth continued as customers value high performance and lower cost of ownership. Revenue and licenses of Windows Server grew against the backdrop of a declining server hardware market. And in the public cloud space, we had another quarter of significant azure usage growth. Additionally, we significantly grew the gross margin percentage in our Commercial Other segment, increasing 13 points to over 43%.
Moving to operating expenses, which declined 9% or 4% in constant currency. Our continued disciplined approach has allowed us to incrementally fund strategic initiatives without having to increase our expense base. Other income was favorable to our expectation, driven by gains on foreign currency and sales with investment. Our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 24% and was at the high-end of our guided range due in part the strong performance in our Computing and Gaming Hardware segment in the U.S.
We returned $6.7 billion to shareholders this quarter, nearly double the amount from last year. With that overview of the current quarter, let me turn to our outlook, starting with the overall comments.
As we as we have communicated over the past couple of months, the accounting for Windows 10 will change. We will be differing a portion of Windows 10 revenue, primarily OEM, and recognizing it over time, generally 2 to 4 years. As shared previously, the initial deferral and the subsequent recognition of those deferrals will be netted in Corporate/Other in our segment reporting. Most importantly, underlying billings and cash flow won't change. Therefore, our commentary into this and subsequent earnings calls, including our guidance, will focus on results prior to the net deferral impact, which we believe is the best reflection of business health. With that background, let me share some thoughts on fiscal '16.
The strengthening of the U.S. dollar will continue to have a significant impact on our results over the course of FY '16. Assuming rates across our largest currencies, the euro, Japanese yen and the British pound stay in line with current rates, and that the geographic mix of revenue stays as forecasted. In our non-annuity businesses, the impact is immediate as the revenue is recognized in quarter. In our annuity business, revenue was deferred and the impact is delayed as we earn the revenue off the balance sheet. In total, we expect the FX will negatively impact total revenue growth by 5 points in each quarter of H1, with 7 points of negative impact in our Commercial segment. H1 would be the peak of the FX headwinds and in H2, we expect FX to have 3 points of negative impact in total and roughly 4 points of negative impact on our commercial revenue.
With Windows 10, we expect momentum to build throughout the year as we and our partners bring new devices, applications and services to market. We expect this to benefit our business results in the second half of the fiscal year. With the strength in Xbox and Xbox Live, along with the launch of Halo 5 in October, Xbox will continue the growth both fans and profitability.
With the recently announced changes in phones, there will be significant revenue declined year-over-year in the phone segment grow each quarter. With the proactive measures we've taken to reduce our cost structure, overall losses will also decline to the fiscal year. We would expect the majority of that improvement in the second half of the year once the restructuring efforts are materially complete.
Bing will be profitable in FY '16. And assuming the macro environment is stable, we expect our commercial momentum will continue, highlighted the growth in our commercial cloud. We remain on track to achieve our $20 billion commercial cloud ambition in fiscal 2018.
We now expect operating expenses to be $32.1 billion to $32.4 billion which is lower than the guidance we provided in April. The lower guidance reflects the savings from our restructuring of the Phone business as well as important investments to drive top line growth as we support Windows 10, our first party hardware efforts as well as headcount to accelerate our leadership position in the Commercial cloud. 
We expect our full year tax rate to be 24%, plus or minus 1 point, excluding the net impact from the Windows 10 deferral.
Now in Q1, starting with Devices and Consumer. In licensing, we expect revenue to be $3.4 billion to $3.6 billion. This range reflects Windows revenue roughly 9 with a PC market. Within Consumer Office, we expect the transition to Office 365 subscriptions to continue. 
In Computing and Gaming Hardware, we expect revenue to be $2.0 billion to $2.1 billion. As a reminder, we launched service Pro 3 in late June last year with launch benefits extending into Q1. 
In Phone Hardware, we expect revenue to be approximately $900 million reflecting our change in approach. We expect gross margin in phone to improve sequentially in Q1. 
In Devices and Consumer other, we expect revenue to be $2.2 billion to $2.3 billion, with continued growth in Bing, Consumer Office 365 and Xbox LIVE transactions.
And in commercial, as I discussed previously, we expect a significant FX headwind this quarter. Our constant currency growth is expected to be about 7% in Q1, which assumes continue to make sure take share in key markets and build momentum in the new areas we have entered. With the negative impact of FX, we expect revenue to be roughly flat.
On Commercial Licensing, we expect revenue of $9.1 billion to $9.2 billion with a continued shift to annuity. And in Commercial Other, with the significant growth in our cloud revenue of $3.1 billion to $3.2 billion.
We expect COGS to be $7.0 billion to $7.2 billion with the variability being driven by the hardware segment. We expect operating expenses to be $7.6 billion to $7.7 billion. As a reminder, other income and expense includes dividend interest income, offset by interest expense and the net cost of hedging. Given the current FX environment, we expect our net cost of hedging to increase and other income and expense to be negative $200 million. 
Excluding the Windows 10 deferrals and the impact of foreign currency, we expect the sequential decline in unearned to be slightly better than historic seasonality, driven by the growing mix of annuity revenue.
In closing, I'm proud of the tremendous amount of progress that our company has made over the past year. We've improved how we operate in virtually every sense. These changes have allowed us to aggressively invest in areas that will drive future growth for the company. I'm looking forward, we're better positioned to capitalize on significant opportunities ahead of us. 
With that, let me turn it back over to Chris for the Q&A.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Phil Winslow from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to double click on Office 365. You guys showed another huge quarter of growth in terms of your consumer seat count and I think it was 86% growth on the Commercial Other side for Office 365. Wondered if you could just drill into both the cons
componenttext: I just wanted to double click on Office 365. You guys showed another huge quarter of growth in terms of your consumer seat count and I think it was 86% growth on the Commercial Other side for Office 365. Wondered if you could just drill into both the consumer and then the enterprise side just the trends you're seeing there and obviously the guidance you all just provided. It looks like you expect those trends to continue in Q1. So any color there would be great.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take that up. Overall, we are very excited by the growth we are seeing in Office 365. On the consumer side, as you noted, we're going 1 million subs a month and that's fantastic growth for us. As the consumer value, especially now that we have e
componenttext: Yes, I'll take that up. Overall, we are very excited by the growth we are seeing in Office 365. On the consumer side, as you noted, we're going 1 million subs a month and that's fantastic growth for us. As the consumer value, especially now that we have even all the endpoints covered with Office, the definition of Office and where all its presence is also changed and that all accrues to consumers being willing to -- to have a subscription relationship with us. On the enterprise side, the growth remains very exciting for us, and the growth comes in multiple forms. It comes in the form of just the EAs renewing more to Office 365. It also comes in the form of some of the more comprehensive suite, the E3 and the new E5 the commitment we are seeing. And we also see small businesses I talked about the 50,000 businesses, small and medium-sized businesses, each month signing up for Office 365. That's pretty unprecedented having been in the servers business all my life. I've never seen a lot of the small business customers adopt from the rich capabilities like it's possible now and that's great growth rate growth as well. And that cloud revenue number, that is the 88%, is all up cloud revenue inclusive of Office 365, EMS and Azure. And it's good to see that then of growth at that kind of scale now with $8 billion.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the one thing I would add, Phil, to that is an important dynamic we're seeing of of Office 365 is as we are having this momentum build and Satya talked about some of the new customers we're adding and some way we see that is installed base growing and
componenttext: And the one thing I would add, Phil, to that is an important dynamic we're seeing of of Office 365 is as we are having this momentum build and Satya talked about some of the new customers we're adding and some way we see that is installed base growing and be able to see that this quarter across all the core workflows and in Office. And when you think about why that's so critical long term is our ability to sell some of workloads Satya actually referenced that will be in E5 when it launches. We have the capability of upgrading on a consistent basis using more of these premium services. So when you can both add to your installed base and add overall market opportunity, we feel good about our line of sight in that business for our long-term goal.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brent Thill from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brent Thill from UBS.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Satya, the server business continues a steady out performance and as Amy pointed out, better growth than your peers. I guess a couple of questions as it relates to the Windows 2003 retirement and any impact you're seeing there? And then secondarily, if yo
componenttext: Satya, the server business continues a steady out performance and as Amy pointed out, better growth than your peers. I guess a couple of questions as it relates to the Windows 2003 retirement and any impact you're seeing there? And then secondarily, if you could just comment on some of the new product launches. It seems like there's a stack of new solutions that are coming on the server side that looked pretty exciting and your partners are excited about it. If you could highlight what you see is the most interesting from your perspective over the next several quarters.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, overall, I'd start with a bird view that my server business is not some legacy business. We fundamentally think about servers as the extension of the cloud I even described it architecture of the advantage of our cloud. Every server, for example, hav
componenttext: Yes, overall, I'd start with a bird view that my server business is not some legacy business. We fundamentally think about servers as the extension of the cloud I even described it architecture of the advantage of our cloud. Every server, for example, have been -- recovery, back up and tearing the cloud. And so we will continue to push that differentiation because I think that view architecture of the and the delivery of it is what makes is pretty unique. And you see it in the numbers. Our servers even this quarter grew 9% and compared to the industry peers, we're obviously gaining share on Windows Server, on SQL Server and pretty much all of our management and security products as well. And going forward, we have a fantastic lineup of servers, not just the infrastructure, but even SharePoint, Exchange, Lync server continues to have significant on-premise deployment. So as our cloud continues to grow, obviously we are getting there is more capability the cloud, we're incentive customers and our partners to move to the cloud. But at the same time, we are going to have a great server wave. I'm excited about our SQL product. I think it goes into the first preview next -- in fact, tomorrow. And that product, I think, is a pretty revolutionary product, because for the first time, you can take a single table in a database and even tier in the cloud at that time but I'd of capability only we can provide and that's something that I'm looking forward to.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And, Brent, to your specific question on Windows Server 2003, we did have a good quarter as we as we talked about in the Windows Server. But in general, that business, unlike the client upgrade that we see, just because a much of the business is already o
componenttext: And, Brent, to your specific question on Windows Server 2003, we did have a good quarter as we as we talked about in the Windows Server. But in general, that business, unlike the client upgrade that we see, just because a much of the business is already on annuity, we don't see that type of mental impact in than in the quarter release. That isn't to say there's ample opportunity first to make sure we have upgrade customers to the higher value props and more secure and more manageable offerings we have in the server business.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mark Moerdler from Bernstein Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mark Moerdler from Bernstein Research.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to drill in in terms of the move to the cloud. This quarter, the year-over-year server products and services revenue growth were slower than in the past quarters. How much of that is because you're seeing now some revenue shift to Azure or is it no
componenttext: I want to drill in in terms of the move to the cloud. This quarter, the year-over-year server products and services revenue growth were slower than in the past quarters. How much of that is because you're seeing now some revenue shift to Azure or is it not yet seen any revenue shift showing? And then I have a follow-up question.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, why don't I take some that one and we'll do a follow-up. At 9% growth and continuing to take share, I feel like our performance and this continues to be sort of a positive outlier to the peer group. And for me, that type of performance in double dig
componenttext: Well, why don't I take some that one and we'll do a follow-up. At 9% growth and continuing to take share, I feel like our performance and this continues to be sort of a positive outlier to the peer group. And for me, that type of performance in double digits for the year, I feel quite good about. In general, what's interesting I think as you're getting to the crux of it, is to we have incremental workloads that are unique to the cloud and I think we continue to see that. The very best example, frankly, Satya mentioned in his comments, which is our EMS performance, Enterprise Mobility Suite offerings. It's just -- it's taking something that's very unique, built off of our core in the service business and allows us to us to both grow and add new perspective there. So I don't think of it as reflecting a bigger shift that we've seen in particular this quarter. Also if you remember a year ago, we had a very big phase of exploration. In Q4 had a very strong performance a year ago. So I don't look at it as a direct trend line.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing I'd add is when you look of the total growth of Azure, the growth that's coming now from some of the premium services, this is the businesses that we actually did not ever participate on-premise at all. Even EMS, when I think about our
componenttext: Yes, the only thing I'd add is when you look of the total growth of Azure, the growth that's coming now from some of the premium services, this is the businesses that we actually did not ever participate on-premise at all. Even EMS, when I think about our management, our management was just about Windows management. But we now have management data protection and identity systems that cross all devices in the enterprise, including Internet of Things, and that makes it pretty exciting and that growth is great to see. On the server management, we of a new suite called the Operations Management Suite, which also spans all the cloud units as well as on-premise units. Cortana Analytics, we never participated in any of the advanced analytics workload at all, in spite of all the success we've had in the database business. And so I'm excited about building you workloads that in many cases are borne in the cloud workload, where we're expanding our market opportunity and continuing to outperform our peers and grab share when it comes to on-premise.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. Switching gears a bit. On Windows, obviously, you're seeing some amount of delay due to Windows 10 on the OEM side. Can you give maybe a little more color in terms of how you're thinking about that, how big a delay is it, how much tha
componenttext: That's very helpful. Switching gears a bit. On Windows, obviously, you're seeing some amount of delay due to Windows 10 on the OEM side. Can you give maybe a little more color in terms of how you're thinking about that, how big a delay is it, how much that starting to be replaced next quarter and beyond?

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take that and, Amy, you can add to it. And the way I -- the Windows ecosystem works is there are places today. And in fact, if anything, the release of Windows 10 just the way we built it with the insider program, everything is of course speedin
componenttext: Yes, I'll take that and, Amy, you can add to it. And the way I -- the Windows ecosystem works is there are places today. And in fact, if anything, the release of Windows 10 just the way we built it with the insider program, everything is of course speeding up because in some sense, we've taken a very different approach with the Windows-as-a-Service even when it comes to OEM relations and how they're able to co-create the products with us. But that's 3 distinct phases. The first phase is what I will describe upgrade phase that will started now be time that is more retail execution and upgrades. Then come the fall, you will see the device from all the OEMs going into the holiday quarter. And then the enterprise upgrade, in fact, we have the release of enterprise features which I mentioned in my script, which will ship in that time frame. And I expect piloting to start and deployments to start in the second half of the fiscal year. So that's how I'll think about the OEM as well as enterprise adoption. So if my bullishness for Windows 10 is more the second half of the this full year. And of course, it will build. It will build starting in a weeks' time in retail and in the upgrades, but I sort of see this in 3 phases.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And to your specific question, Mark, before every launch, we tend to have a tightening in the that channel as we prepare and run a reasonably lean this is a healthy state, it's within the range of normal. So I don't think of it as a delay in the way you'r
componenttext: And to your specific question, Mark, before every launch, we tend to have a tightening in the that channel as we prepare and run a reasonably lean this is a healthy state, it's within the range of normal. So I don't think of it as a delay in the way you're talking about it. It is pretty standard, as Satya talked about, in terms of the dynamic. And he mentioned we are feeling I think a lot of excitement from the ecosystem about what's possible with some of the new devices that will come. And so I really don't think about it that way. I think about it as an encouragement that they want to fill the channel as quickly as they can't over the coming quarters with their machine.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Keith Weiss from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Keith Weiss from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to drill into sort of the new strategy around the phone business a little bit. The revenue expectation for Q1 is below our expectations, I think you're going below what the Street was looking for. Can you give us a sense of sense of how we see th
componenttext: I wanted to drill into sort of the new strategy around the phone business a little bit. The revenue expectation for Q1 is below our expectations, I think you're going below what the Street was looking for. Can you give us a sense of sense of how we see that sense of how easy that business tracking over longer periods of time? Because there's significant restructuring going on, I think I don't think a lot of guys will have very good view out of their head of what your expedition for this business on the revenue run rate basis or what do you expect to be selling this year and on a going-forward basis is right now?

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start and then, Amy, you can add to this. The big shift that we're making when it comes to phones is to not think about phones in isolation. That's perhaps the biggest shift. Because I think about Windows 10 in its entirety, the Windows ecosystem i
componenttext: Let me start and then, Amy, you can add to this. The big shift that we're making when it comes to phones is to not think about phones in isolation. That's perhaps the biggest shift. Because I think about Windows 10 in its entirety, the Windows ecosystem in its entirety. We clearly are going to have premium first-party portfolio and you've seen so the numbers, some the progress we've made in Surface. I feel that we have a formula there that I would like to apply more broadly in terms of growing -- just delivering innovation, growing our own economic return for it, stimulating demand, creating categories, all of that is what I want do to broadly, it applies to phones, it applies to Surface hub and it applies HoloLens, and that's how I view it. I believe our participation to the phone segment by itself by Windows Phones and Lumia phones being there is important and that's why we picked the 3 areas where we have differentiation and we want to focus on it. We want to have great flagship phones for Windows SaaS. That's actually a segment we don't today have a good devices, and we hope to change that with Windows 10. We have, in fact, good traction in the business segments. This is a business customers who are actually buying phone this of phone devices, which is basically a radio with essentially a smartphone, to be able to deploy their line of business applications. That's where we have pretty unparalleled value, which as we have the Visual Studio Online at some of the tools I talked about. So you can generate these apps at a low cost of ownership, manage them, secure them and deploy them to our phone endpoints and then of course management and security. So that's the place where we are going to continue to focus. And then the value smartphone, that's the place where I want us to be much more efficient. We clearly have some value to add there because of the uniqueness of Office and Skype and our services. But at the same time, I think we want to be smart about how many of these phones do we want to generate, how many -- which price points we want to participate. That's where you'll see the most significant operational changes from how we operated last year to the coming year.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so, Keith, the way that I think about it, I tried to outline it in my comments is that the significant revenue declines quarter-over-quarter and for the year are a reflection of the focused approach we are going to take in phone. It's an approach that
componenttext: And so, Keith, the way that I think about it, I tried to outline it in my comments is that the significant revenue declines quarter-over-quarter and for the year are a reflection of the focused approach we are going to take in phone. It's an approach that we've executed in other hardware segment that I feel is a proven model for us. Our profitability will also improve. More of that comes in the second half of the year structurally as we complete some of the restructuring efforts in those costs come out of our operating expense run rate. But I think that's probably the way to more appropriately think about, over time, you would expect to see gross margin improvement and operating profit improvement as opposed to focusing on the revenue line.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And if I could take one more and just on the security side of the business. I think a lot of you guys security something that Microsoft does to make your more secure and to provide more confident users using your platforms and your tools. On a going-forwa
componenttext: And if I could take one more and just on the security side of the business. I think a lot of you guys security something that Microsoft does to make your more secure and to provide more confident users using your platforms and your tools. On a going-forward basis, is there more of an opportunity for you guys sell security as more of a standalone opportunity? I mean, it's something that's very high demand looking for more secure solution. Potentially more of a standalone opportunity for Microsoft on a go-forward basis?

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: In fact, we are adding significant value in security. It's much better for us, for example, to add capability there are Office 365 and security and that's all in, for example, the Newsweek that we have just announced call the E5, the secure lockbox. That'
componenttext: In fact, we are adding significant value in security. It's much better for us, for example, to add capability there are Office 365 and security and that's all in, for example, the Newsweek that we have just announced call the E5, the secure lockbox. That's actually a very cool set of figure features that allow both regulators and businesses to have, for example, auditability and control over there move into the cloud. Similarly, Azure, where we launched a new set of security offers around people can encrypt and manage keys, so those are all security features. We bought a company in Colorado that's a firewall on all your at that identity management. So when we talk about enterprise management suite growth, a lot of it is obviously management growth but it's also security and data protection growth. So the approach we're taking is we're essentially creating, to your point, security value around our products, which allows us to participate in essentially a security market that we never did in the way they we are. So it's more than just launching one point security product. It's much more broadly participating in the security market and you've seen some that in the inorganic move and the suites we have created.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Walter Pritchard from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Walter Pritchard from Citi.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Amy, just for you on the annuity, it looks like annuities about 82% of the commercial revenue the last 2 quarters. How high do you think that goes? It sounds like you do expect that to continue to go up although probably never gets up to 100%.
componenttext: Amy, just for you on the annuity, it looks like annuities about 82% of the commercial revenue the last 2 quarters. How high do you think that goes? It sounds like you do expect that to continue to go up although probably never gets up to 100%.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do think, our -- over the long term, you're right, that is how I think about it. And frankly inherent in the conversation around moving to the cloud with aggressive targets we've given values sort of imply to your point. And so I think 100% is not
componenttext: Yes, I do think, our -- over the long term, you're right, that is how I think about it. And frankly inherent in the conversation around moving to the cloud with aggressive targets we've given values sort of imply to your point. And so I think 100% is not the logical answer. There will always be somebody who chooses to purchase on a one-time basis, or there's a logic to it. But I do think over time, we do expect that the trend in that general direction.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, Satya, you mentioned CRM in your comments, your prepared comments, which we haven't really heard you talk as much about is an area of interest in the past. I'm wondering what changed in your view, or how do you look to sort of bring that into so
componenttext: And then, Satya, you mentioned CRM in your comments, your prepared comments, which we haven't really heard you talk as much about is an area of interest in the past. I'm wondering what changed in your view, or how do you look to sort of bring that into sounds like more of the core productivity scenario that you deliver?

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean overall, business process collaborations, communication, these category boundaries are things that I believe are going to change. I've always felt that sometimes, most of the time, we even automate business processes where we spent really gett
componenttext: Yes, I mean overall, business process collaborations, communication, these category boundaries are things that I believe are going to change. I've always felt that sometimes, most of the time, we even automate business processes where we spent really getting our business plan in our communication and collaboration tools. And this impedes something that I've always dreamt up a sort of how do we go for? And CRM our own Dynamics product has taken some pretty unique approaches. And quite friendly, I was -- open up our up communication and collaboration for other CRM one of the things that I'm very explicit about is we will have an open platform for other business process applications because of the very fragmented market especially if you add SMB. And so we want to be having a platform play, as well as our own business applications play and both of them should be high growth for us. And in the last year, we've just added more focus and be put more selling capacity around it, more marketing capacity and now for the mainstream across Microsoft, because I'm a big believer in this. Because I think we have something unique to add as opposed to driving our own top line, bottom line growth I think we can bring real innovation. That is what this exciting to see. And it's not just CRM, I'm actually excited about our year it ERP business. Some of the numbers that Amy talked about is growth in the seats. And when I think about the as the new currency, we have lots of managed seats and a lot of data, which I will move to the cloud. And so things like Power BI, Cortana Analytics can help customers transform. So in fact, that's one of the reasons why I'm even sort of very optimistic about some of our you data capabilities is we have the attach capability to go out installed base of Dynamics.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And, Walter, just quickly, this is one of the areas that we invested in actually leading into this past fiscal year FY '15 and the results had actually been better than we anticipated when we first made the investment. So I think we both feel very good ab
componenttext: And, Walter, just quickly, this is one of the areas that we invested in actually leading into this past fiscal year FY '15 and the results had actually been better than we anticipated when we first made the investment. So I think we both feel very good about the momentum that's built through the year.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Question for Amy on the cost control front. Looks like you once again came in below your OpEx guy. But I think the COGS number came a little bit about what you had guided to 3 months ago question and I'm just wondering if you could talk through that. Obvi
componenttext: Question for Amy on the cost control front. Looks like you once again came in below your OpEx guy. But I think the COGS number came a little bit about what you had guided to 3 months ago question and I'm just wondering if you could talk through that. Obviously it affects everybody's gross margin calculations. Was it the hardware mix shift? Was it the challenges with a Phone business? Perhaps a little color there might help us.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Karl. Because of the performance in Xbox and in Surface, you're right, it is a hardware mix shift of it. We outperformed significantly in both those products in Q4, and that does Surface, a little bit outside the COGS range but not as much as our re
componenttext: Sure, Karl. Because of the performance in Xbox and in Surface, you're right, it is a hardware mix shift of it. We outperformed significantly in both those products in Q4, and that does Surface, a little bit outside the COGS range but not as much as our revenue outperformed. So actually, margin structurally were better than I thought they would be. And so I actually feel quite good with that outperformance in our ability to see that outperformance fall to the bottom line through stronger execution on gross margin percentage, particularly in that segment.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Raimo Lenschow from Barclays.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to Azure, you obviously have strong momentum there. Can you talk a little bit about the use cases you see from your enterprise and SMB customers? Does this kind of very much test and development situation or are you seeing kind of a br
componenttext: I wanted to go back to Azure, you obviously have strong momentum there. Can you talk a little bit about the use cases you see from your enterprise and SMB customers? Does this kind of very much test and development situation or are you seeing kind of a broader adoption that because besides obviously Office 365, et cetera?

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: At this point, I'd say it's pretty broad even used cases for even enterprise customers. There is definitely Deb test happening, there's production IAS infrastructure as a service deployment, given some of the new high-performance SKUs and storage options
componenttext: At this point, I'd say it's pretty broad even used cases for even enterprise customers. There is definitely Deb test happening, there's production IAS infrastructure as a service deployment, given some of the new high-performance SKUs and storage options that we have. And we're seeing significant adoption of SQL services, this is Azure DB, machine learning as a service what of the things that we realize that every company out there becomes a software company beyond even our traditional beach through IT, everyone has a digital office inside their company. They are in fact doing things in advanced analytics and using machine learning and as the place where we have some very unique capability. So that's another place where we think wide adoption. We are seeing adoption in the building of new front end to new back end eventually using Azure as the cloud backend for their mobile apps across Android, iOS and Windows as well as their web. That's another use case that's high-growth for us. And of course, Cortana Analytics, this is the big data side of this. This is happening in IT, it's happening in, as I said digital offices within each one of the customers. So we have a pretty broad spectrum of use cases that some of the customers have talked about even in the recent set of conferences from our partner conference to our Ignite conference. We'll in fact showcasing even our ad campaign showcases some of these use cases.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Heather Bellini from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Heather Bellini from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had 2 questions, pretty quick ones. Just to follow-up on Azure, I was wondering if you could share with us what you're seeing in the mix between IAS and PaaS and kind of how you've seen that shift over the last few quarters. And then secondly, just
componenttext: I just had 2 questions, pretty quick ones. Just to follow-up on Azure, I was wondering if you could share with us what you're seeing in the mix between IAS and PaaS and kind of how you've seen that shift over the last few quarters. And then secondly, just a follow-up I think on Walter's question. Yes, you definitely have been focusing on the Customer Relationship Management opportunity and the financial market more. But given the big SaaS companies already competing in that area, can you share with us -- do you think you have the assets you need internally to execute against your long-term goals?

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the IAS and PaaS, it's interesting question, we don't look at it in isolation, because what happens is you keep the used cases what starts off as IAS suddenly will use Azure AD for identity management, will use a little bit of our Media Services,
componenttext: Sure. On the IAS and PaaS, it's interesting question, we don't look at it in isolation, because what happens is you keep the used cases what starts off as IAS suddenly will use Azure AD for identity management, will use a little bit of our Media Services, for example, just doing content encoding. So there's a mix always. So there's nothing pure paas, nothing pure IaaS. That's the trend I see, but it's a split we should go take a look at them and off-line, maybe even talk about it. But the overall, we see significant amount of IaaS in the last year because that's probably the place where we had more of a weakness, which we've now overcome. And so we're seeing significant growth of IaaS in the enterprise. But a place where we continue to have significant differentiation is in some of these managed services at PaaS and I think that's the mix on it. And then on the Dynamics side, I leads we have a huge opportunity. Having sort of absolutely worked in business applications for a long time, first of all, the market is very fragmented. I think people like to talk about leaders, and there are clear leaders, clearly viewed as when you go to the very top of the enterprise customers and segment, they verticals and into horizontal 7 of the platform effect, there's plenty of opportunity. For sure, you've got to be one of the players. It will be 3 players, 4 players, whatever. But in every technology paradigm, you want to be one of them. You already have a $2-plus billion Dynamics business I talked about the number of seats and now we have this triple digit CRM Online growth. So I feel that we're in a good position and I feel that we'll look at the given some the inorganic means to keep doing it. In fact, the field service acquisition I talked about in my script is an example of that. So that's why bullishness on our business process prospect.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross MacMillan from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, on OpEx, the guidance, Amy, is impressive. I presume that fully accommodates the restructuring announced 2 weeks ago. And then last year, you said core Microsoft at NDS will be down slightly in OpEx. I wondered if you could provide a similar commen
componenttext: First, on OpEx, the guidance, Amy, is impressive. I presume that fully accommodates the restructuring announced 2 weeks ago. And then last year, you said core Microsoft at NDS will be down slightly in OpEx. I wondered if you could provide a similar comment for fiscal '16 for core Microsoft x phone.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I talked a little bit about it but let me go into a bit of detail on that. I think the first half of your question was does that $32.1 billion to $32.4 billion full year OpEx guide reflect the timing of the implementation of our restructuring,
componenttext: Sure. Well, I talked a little bit about it but let me go into a bit of detail on that. I think the first half of your question was does that $32.1 billion to $32.4 billion full year OpEx guide reflect the timing of the implementation of our restructuring, and it certainly does. And so what you can then see released to the second half of your question is that we are taking some of those savings and investing them back into the business in some of these key growth areas we've seen. I outlined 3 on the call. The third one  I probably could have expanded more on. The first one is Windows 10. The second is the first party hardware, where we just had such terrific performance again this Q4. And then finally, the third bucket was about accelerating our Commercial cloud lead. And I do feel that in that area, we could invest in Office 365, some of the new E5 capability to my look forward to adding sales capacity to take advantage with that. We'll also add sales capacity across some of the other opportunities we've seen broadly. So I look and see that as an opportunity to accelerate top line growth.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And one thing I'll just add biggest folks even asked about business process and business applications. I want to build a long-term, profitable business. In other words, one of the keys in these apps is you can always get into the trap of overspending in m
componenttext: And one thing I'll just add biggest folks even asked about business process and business applications. I want to build a long-term, profitable business. In other words, one of the keys in these apps is you can always get into the trap of overspending in marketing and not having long-term leverage at all. One thing I feel very good about our position is how do you really build a long-term profitable business. That's front and center to me. So we will not overspend there in sales and marketing because we do believe that products in fact different ways to sell even business process applications because of the cloud, and that's something that you want to take advantage of.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had one quick follow-up, if I could. That's helpful. Analyst Day, I talked about I think it was 8% unit growth in Office ecosystem over the last 2 years, and it sounds like you continue to see nice Office unit growth in Office. How should we think about
componenttext: I had one quick follow-up, if I could. That's helpful. Analyst Day, I talked about I think it was 8% unit growth in Office ecosystem over the last 2 years, and it sounds like you continue to see nice Office unit growth in Office. How should we think about that going forward? Are you fully expected to do need to see unit growth? And then also just a clarification, if your customer lifetime value was based on existing SKUs. So as you introduce E5 and others, does that open up the potential for even higher customer lifetime value?

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I do think the work we showed in the Analyst Meeting on the importance of increasing the installed base across Office and Exchange, but it did occur again this quarter so I feel good that we're staying on the trajectory that we showed in the projec
componenttext: Great. I do think the work we showed in the Analyst Meeting on the importance of increasing the installed base across Office and Exchange, but it did occur again this quarter so I feel good that we're staying on the trajectory that we showed in the projection. To continue to expect that to happen as we share back that last week in April. And on your -- on the second half of your question, I tend to think -- you're right. Generically, each of the examples are quite different. There were people that were upgrading from x to y, there were people that were just simply moving to the cloud. But one of the things that cloud makes fundamentally possible is the opportunity for us to quickly iterate the opportunities, build value and deploy it more quickly to customers and generally, I do think that they will pay us for that to your specific question. And I also think the importance of it is it tends to also come with higher margin. So our improvement and continued improvement in our Commercial cloud gross margin portfolio, I think this is a key criteria of that. So I associate it yes, with Life-Time-Value yes, I socially ability to move our gross margin percentage up.

componenttext: Just one last one on M&A. And maybe you can just talk through changing the strategy what's happening with key write-down, security acquisition pivotal fiscal year, how you're thinking about M&A given everything especially as you guys have been pretty tight in cost controls and everything else.

headline: Microsoft Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Overall, Dan, the way I look at it is where -- first of all, I'm most focused on obviously, our organic growth. And in there, Amy alluded to this. We made significant changes in how we've allocated our own organic dollars, both in R&D as well as in sales
componenttext: Overall, Dan, the way I look at it is where -- first of all, I'm most focused on obviously, our organic growth. And in there, Amy alluded to this. We made significant changes in how we've allocated our own organic dollars, both in R&D as well as in sales and marketing and we'll continue to do that. Because I think there is significant opportunities for us to go after, and that will require just reallocating it gradually, and that to me is core. But beyond that, we will look at inorganic means. But I look at all the acquisitions that we have made over the course of the last year and our OpEx guidance for next year shows how disciplined we are in bringing new talent in, be it in R&D, be it in sales and marketing. So we are not afraid to bring in new capability. But that also questioning what is the allocation we have. And of course, we've done smaller acquisitions. They can add up. They are pretty significant when you add up all the things that we have done in the Office 365 space, all the things that we did in the Azure space, and so we'll continue to do that. And if anything comes up in M&A, which allows us to pursue our strategic vision that we will need to even allocate more to on on OpEx basis, post-acquisition, we will look at that. So I won't shy away from it because what's important to us is within areas where we have something unique to contribute and long-term profitability.
